subtitle: For the very first volume of the New Thinking Allowed Dialogue series,
Is There Life After Death? Publication date is June 1st.
Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is psychotronics.
With me is Dr. Beverly Rubick, who is the
President of the United States Psychotronics
Association.
Beverly is a biophysicist.
She is the founder and director of the Institute
for Frontier Science in Oakland, California
and is the author of over 100 scientific papers on
subtle energies, psychic healing, the mysterious
properties of water and other frontier areas of science.
Welcome Beverly.
Thank you, Jeffrey.
It's my pleasure.
I first heard of the term psychotronics after
reading Psychic Discoveries Behind the Iron
Curtain.
I think there was a chapter in that book which
was published back in the 1960s about work
going on in Czechoslovakia.
I gather that the term caught on and there was an international association and then
the American Association.
Over the past half century, people have been working in this mysterious area.
Yes.
The original psychotronics was a remake of parapsychology by the Czech group because
they felt it was a little mystical or it had
a bad reputation so they wanted to rescue it.
They also started to move into studying devices,
shapes such as pyramids and really new inventions
to which they applied intent.
The word psychotronics really means mind and machine, mind and device.
It's all about the mind-machine interface, at least originally.
This goes back to ancient times in a way.
There are what were known as amulets.
People carried special charms and devices and
signias and so forth, even special clothing
with various images on it for purposes of warding off evil spirits and the like.
Absolutely.
I think in the past when we had more handiwork,
people put something of themselves in the
very creations that they made and they believed
that there were some special properties as
a result of their intention of being imbued in the matter.
And of course, mystics throughout history
have worked with objects, whether it's crystal
balls or specially charged wands or holy water,
all of the interaction between the human being
and various material substances or devices goes back a long way.
Fling rods are also another example.
Yes.
The original willow that people walked around
to find water that they say simply moved.
But in reality, I don't think there's any special property to the matter per se.
It's something about the coupling between the human being and the device.
Well, there's no question that humans can augment their natural abilities by various
devices.
The simplest one is a pencil.
If I have a pencil, I can perform complex mathematical operations.
My brain is doing all the work, but without the pencil, it would be quite hard.
Yes.
That's a very good example.
And there are devices used in radionics that
look extremely complicated, that involve a
witness where you take a snippet of fingernail
or hair or sometimes a photograph of the target,
might be a person, might be an agricultural field, place it into a well.
And then they assess it to look for what rates,
what so-called frequencies might influence it.
Actually, they first try to assess what's wrong with it, and then they assess rates
to which they will broadcast apparently some
subtle energy to the target to effectively
produce the desired change, health or improved yields, et cetera.
Now, you and I both knew Arthur M. Young, who was a mentor of mine, the inventor of
the Bell helicopter, who was an avid student of radionics.
That's interesting about Arthur, yes.
I remember he used the Brundler scale to evaluate
one's development, which was very intriguing.
And he worked very closely with Francis Farley,
who was a skilled and even famous radionics
practitioner.
Yes.
And I learned from her, this was her attitude,
that the machine was, the radionics device
to her was nothing more than training wheels.
And once she got to a certain point, she didn't
need it anymore, just like someone learning
to ride a bicycle.
So you need the training wheels to balance, and
then eventually you can ride a bike without.
But there are really a couple of other viewpoints on this.
There are people who believe it's all in the
mind, it's all about us and our abilities
and simply extending them a little help to focus in the device.
And there are those who are the gear heads, who think it's all in the devices.
And then there are those who think, it's a little bit of both.
Well, I'm inclined to take a pragmatic approach to this.
And if it works for somebody, if they're getting
results, then their belief system, whatever
it may be, is part of the system that produces
those results, then for those people that
belief system is true, even if it's not true for someone else.
I think that's very important, I would agree.
Because people have taken even visual diagrams
of radionics machines, drawn on paper, so
there's really no circuits.
And they're just simply pen lines showing struck schematics, and then they use this
in the same manner.
And as long as they believe it, it works.
But if there was a line missing which they thought should be there, it didn't work.
So there you go, there's the biology of belief again.
Well, we do know that belief is very powerful.
The placebo effect is one of the most powerful
effects in all of medicine, for example.
And the human mind is quite mysterious.
And some of these psychic procedures are very complex.
You have to go through a certain recipe, step
by step by step, in order to get the right
result, and to have a device that can help guide
you through those steps, I think, is useful.
Absolutely, yes.
So there's a little bit of the target, whether
it's a banana or a picture of your agricultural
field that goes into a well, so you can focus on that.
And then you have a way of asking questions,
yes or no, by running your fingers over a
plate and looking for a yes, which would be a stickiness, and a no, which would be
a smoothness.
Yeah.
But actually, the original dowsing I heard was two fingers together, and a stickiness
meant a yes, and a smoothness meant a no, so you didn't really need an instrument.
It's right here.
Well, one could say that the most sophisticated
psychotronic instrument of all is our biological
organism.
Right.
That's right.
We have enormous capability right here in our
own bodies, far more than we could comprehend.
Yes.
But again, we live in a world in which it's
not so commonly considered, so we need a little
help.
I think that's what...
And I know also, your research entails looking
at questions like, how do certain shapes,
like a pyramid shape or a spiral shape, how
do they structure the space within them, and
are there unusual properties when space is structured by shape?
Yes.
This is a key question.
And many years ago, science believed in the ether.
The ether, the luminiferous ether, as it was
called in science, was a primordial substance,
very, very, very subtle, that filled space, and that could be structured.
And there was the medium through which light
waves traveled, and radio waves, and all the
radian energies of the universe.
But there were some key experiments by Michelson
and Morley that didn't show the extent of
what was expected to be called ether drag.
And so science threw out this ether.
But I think we actually need a concept that space has a physicality to it.
It is not empty.
It's not really a vacuum.
Even in quantum theory, there's a zero point energy.
And it's considered a random motion of primordial
particles that maybe we can extract energy
from someday.
But according to conventional science, we would need energy in order to organize this
random mass of particles moving, so they don't go there.
But I think already the ether has some structure.
It's not all purely random.
So it's a very interesting area, mind matter and ether.
These fundamental questions in science always come back.
And I realize as a scientist, we don't know fundamentally what really is matter.
We don't know fundamentally what really is mind, and we don't really know about space
and time either.
We have some ideas, and we've inherited a lot of the cosmologies from Einstein.
But even Einstein held the idea of an ether.
It wasn't the naive ether of the times before
him, but there are papers by Einstein that
mention ether.
I see.
Yes.
Well, one of the great pioneers today in the
field of psychotronics is Dr. William Tiller,
former professor of material science at Stanford University.
He's been working in exotic areas like dowsing and psychotronics for decades.
And he's come up with some amazing devices.
Yes.
He has something called an intention host device, or IHD.
And it's an electronic circuit.
It looks like a black box, actually, and in one of his white papers on his website, you
can find at least some details of the schematic.
And he has people program these devices.
I believe it's a group of meditators who focus
on a specific intention as they meditate around
this device, which is at that time not hooked
into a circuit, but just placed in the middle
of a group.
And so they imbue it with their intention.
And then he may send this device to another laboratory along with a control device and
labeled in such a way that they don't know, which is the sham device or which was the
program device.
And then they use the device in a circuit, and they look for an effect.
For example, he had programmed his IHD to increase the acidity of water, decrease the
pH, or increase the pH, make it more alkaline.
And sure enough, results show, and they're highly statistical significantly, so P less
than 0.01 or 0.01, that this can be done, and that mind can somehow imbue intent into
a device, a circuit-type device, that later can store this information, be shipped to
another laboratory, and show a physical effect.
So that's a really remarkable thing, and very well controlled.
You have to trust Dr. Tiller's work, because
he's a really good scientist, and he's done
this for 30, 40 years.
Well, that's very interesting.
It strikes me that it's a little bit reminiscent
of what is known in parapsychology as, not
psychotronics, but psychometrics, or psychometry,
where a gifted psychic can hold in their
hand an object, typically, let's say, from an archaeological dig, an ancient object,
and there are impressions that they read from
the object so they can describe its history,
how it was used.
It's as if the people who handled that object,
maybe centuries or millennia ago, have left
impressions on the object itself.
So somehow material is storing information, and space can do this as well.
Tiller talks about conditioned space, where you do something over and over again, and
one wonders if that isn't how special sacred
sites seem to always have healings to places
like Lourdes or the Ganges.
What is it?
Is it the power of many healings that have occurred there, as well as the miracle that
may have started it all?
Well, we have this concept called numinosity.
It's used in many different contexts where if you go to a sacred site, the pyramids in
Egypt, people all seem to have a certain reaction
there, or certain cathedrals that are centuries
old where people have been going to these locations and entering into altered states
of consciousness.
One might even say higher states of consciousness over centuries.
These places become imbued with a sense of
the numinous, the inner essence that you could
even say the spiritual quality of these places.
We know they make good remote viewing targets.
A cathedral is a much better remote viewing target, for example, than a warehouse.
Very good.
Well, I've done some studies on the pyramid shape.
It's just simply made out of wooden, the outline, bare outline of the pyramid with
two-inch pine.
They were four foot in diameter.
We used pyramids to study seed germination and plant growth.
We also did an arm of that experiment was to
look at how psychic healing across distance,
of space and time, might also influence the plants.
We had four groups of plants, total control, no pyramid, no healing.
We had a group of healers send into the future
intention to make these plants grow better.
Then we had the pyramid alone, and we had the pyramid coupled with the healers.
The net result is this.
We didn't see the seeds germinate any faster.
They all germinated at the same rate.
However, the healer treated, and it was treated
a month before the actual seeds were planted.
Pre-cognitive healing.
It was 1,000 miles away from my laboratory where I ran a workshop at a conference in
Boulder, Colorado.
Pre-cognitive, distant healing.
Pre-cognitive, distant healing.
We got about 21% more biomass in those plants
that were healer treated, 19% more biomass
in the pyramid treated plants, and over 31%
increase in biomass when we combined pyramid
with energy, healer intent.
So it seemed to show a synergistic effect.
It seemed to boost the influence of conscious intent.
Well, the problem, I imagine, that you would
have sharing that research with people is
that it's sort of mind-blowing.
When we talk about pre-cognitive, distant healing, the first reaction of many people,
maybe most people, is that's impossible, that
can't happen, and therefore there must be
something wrong with what you did or with how you're interpreting it.
Well, all I can say is these are the numbers,
and they are statistically significant.
I know it seems outrageous, but we have to think, again, about fundamentals here.
Because consciousness probably has a real existence outside of space-time, as we know
it in this dimension, I think that's the only way it can be possible.
Einstein might refer to the ancient Vedantic
scriptures that suggest that space and time
themselves emerge out of consciousness.
Einstein said that space and time were not real,
but conditions into which we find ourselves.
And if I recall correctly, Immanuel Kant and
his critique of pure reason suggest that space
and time are categories imposed on reality by
our brains and nervous system, that they're
unique to us and maybe not to the universe itself at all.
We see things according to the way our biological systems are structured.
Yes, and earlier we were talking about psychometry.
You know, I had a remarkable experience of that which goes beyond ordinary space and
time.
Someone's handed me a rock and said, what are your impressions?
It was really a very ordinary-looking desert
rock, and I actually, it made my hand so hot
I had to drop it.
I almost hit my feet, and I said, it's so hot I can hardly hold it.
I said, what's the history of this stone?
They said it was in the first nuclear bomb detonation.
So that was a very hot …
Because you weren't picking up on the physical heat, I presume.
No, it wasn't a physical heat.
It was probably at room temperature.
But I have to say that it began to get so warm that my tendency was to drop it.
Because you were tuning into the vibrational history of the object itself.
So many people who have a knack for invention
and some attunement or opening to the realm
of psychic possibilities are looking at various devices.
These people tend to congregate around the theme of psychotronics.
Yes, I mean there's groups of dowsers, for example, as well as other groups that just
use radionics devices.
There's radioesthesia, which is a whole other thing.
So putting pendulum over the body and assessing areas, diseases, etc.
But I think the pendulum is a useful tool.
There's nothing magical about a bob and a string.
But again, subtle muscular movements in one direction or another will make it rotate.
And that's what people are looking for.
And so a yes might be clockwise, a no might be counterclockwise.
It depends on how you sort of program yourself via suggestion.
Because it's picking up on the subtle autonomic muscle movements.
Your subconscious mind is actually affecting the pendulum.
Yeah, and it's magnifying it because it's a loose object on a string.
So it can magnify this twitch that you may not be able to tell.
But there you go, you read the pendulum and it gives you information.
And people douse with the pendulum, but people also douse maps.
And I knew the great Terry Ross, he was a very famous dowser, not only locally, but
map dowser.
He could find water from just dowsing a map.
And how do you do that?
How do you explain that?
But there are dowsers who go with the fork stick and they're walking over land.
In fact, many people today find water through
dowsing, and not just water, oil, and minerals
as well.
But they claim there's a real physical effect.
This is not me, my autonomic muscle movement.
That dowsing rod is pulling me.
That's how it seems to them, I guess.
And some people think certain dowsing rods' shapes have more efficacy than others to do
the job.
So there's all these varieties from the yellow
rods to the one with the spring in it, et cetera.
Well, you also have people, many people,
who work with crystals for healing purposes.
Yes, I'm thinking back to Marcel Vogel.
And I used to visit him after he kind of
retired from IBM and he had his own laboratory.
And he was always using quartz crystals to do amazing things.
He had a great big microscope and he would
try to crystallize a salt solution on a glass
slide while he used his crystal.
But he used his intention to make, for example,
the Virgin Mary as an image crystallize in
the salt.
And lo and behold, he could do this.
And we saw it with our own eyes.
He claimed that he needed the crystal to do it.
I actually studied a few healers who used
crystals in treating bacterial cultures over
the years.
And then I said, well, let's try it without the crystal.
And it didn't work so well for them.
And yet, I think so much of their being is tied up with it's about me and the crystal
and maybe the belief.
And it's really hard to tease that out as a factor during science.
So we don't really have the answers.
How much is the device?
How much is the person?
This is a tough call.
Well, one of the bugaboos of parapsychology and research of this sort is what's called
the experimenter effect, that if you as an experimenter have a cherished hypothesis,
even if you're doing a triple blind study,
you could be influencing the outcome through
telepathy or psychokinesis.
So if you assume as you begin to accept the
possibility of telepathy, psychokinesis being
real, then you realize there's no way you can prevent a potential experimenter effect
from contaminating the results of your experiment.
If it's a parapsychological experimenter effect.
I know.
We're always concerned about that.
And when I did experiments like this, I
always created an interview form for myself.
So on a given day, I would talk about how do I feel today, what are my expectations
for this experiment, et cetera.
But seems to me that from the science
research that I've done, it's like a teamwork.
You bring in the psychic, but it's really
about the psychic alignment and power of the
group.
Everybody in the system, including people in
the future who will be reading your report.
I think so.
It's hard to draw the line.
When you close the laboratory door, who else
has a vested interest in this experiment whose
thought process may be influencing it.
So it's a complex thing when we study fields
and unbounded things like consciousness.
Now we mentioned earlier that the field of psychotronics, the word psychotronics came
out of Czechoslovakia.
And I know there was some remarkable results
published in the early years of what they
were doing.
Do you have, have they continued that work?
Are you aware of any progress coming out of that part of the world?
I don't know what's going on in the Czech
Republic nowadays, but I do know that the Russians
have installed a number of pyramids on oil wells, rather steep pyramids.
They experimented with different angles of the pyramids.
You know, the great pyramid of Chiafs, it's
not equilateral, it's flatter, and it's based
on the golden mean.
Then there's equilateral triangles.
The Russians are using steep pyramids, foresighted,
but more like church staples placed on oil wells.
And they claim that it decreases the oil viscosity.
And so for the same amount of energy expended, they can mine more oil.
So they're using it for very practical things.
And would you call that a psychotronic effect?
I would, because I do think that their belief
is wrapped up in that to some extent, as well
as their studies.
But it's really difficult, because did they study a cube?
Did they study a sphere?
Is there something special about the pyramid?
Everyone was ecstatic to look at the ancient
pyramids and realize there's a bunch of these
all over the earth from different civilizations.
What was that really all about?
I don't think it was just burial grounds.
There's something more.
Now, I tend to think the pyramids were initiation chambers.
I've been inside the king's chamber in the great pyramid, where there's a sarcophagus.
I've been in the sarcophagus.
Other people with me were in that sarcophagus.
And almost to a person, in fact, I don't know of any exceptions, really.
People report a very particular altered state of consciousness.
When you're in that particular sarcophagus, it's the feeling of floating through outer
space.
You're out amongst the stars.
And it seems to me that conventionally speaking,
engineers and conventional scientists try
to completely discount that their attitudes,
their consciousness would have any effect
on their results, on their experiments and on their equipment, that it should make no
difference whatsoever.
But in fact, there are many, many, many examples
of how people's consciousness does affect
the equipment.
There are some people who they walk into a room and the equipment will stop working.
Yes.
Yes.
Or, yeah, break down.
That does concern me.
And I get phone calls from people like that a lot.
I don't want to invite them to my laboratory.
So we know that the human-machine interface is
far more complex than normally acknowledged.
Exactly.
And of course, that was the study of Robert John and Brenda Dunn for so many years at
the Princeton Engineering Anomalies Research Lab.
Oh, yes.
Because the engineers were concerned about, I
can imagine, especially the aerospace industry,
subtle interactions between the intents and expectations and feelings of pilots and how
instrumentation might change.
So they found effects on random number generators
that were small, a few bits in 10,000, but
highly reproducible over many operators, over many years.
They found reliability in those scores.
So operators thinking about higher numbers got higher numbers, and operators thinking
about lower numbers got lower numbers, and that's how that works.
Well, and those random event generators, or
random number generators, are based on quantum
mechanical principles, are about as random as is physically possible to create.
And to my understanding, they are also at the basis of all of the slot machines here
in Las Vegas.
There's a sense in which the whole city of
Las Vegas is a big parapsychology laboratory.
That's great.
Uh-huh.
And I know one researcher, Dean Rayton, has actually worked with casino managers to see
are there correlations between the casino
winnings and such things as the phases of the
moon?
Well, and then I think the geocosmic factor is a whole other thing.
And I do think we're being shifted all the time.
And we tend to think of the universe as pretty
stable, the sun as stable, the earth as stable.
But actually, the heavenly bodies are whirring
through new regions of space time out there.
And the earth and the sun enter new regions
that might have more or less galactic energy.
And so we could feel something different tomorrow that we didn't feel today.
And the notion of replicability in science,
which depends on the sameness, may be a flawed
notion.
In other words, people always say, OK, you got it once.
Keep replicating.
But everybody knows the thousandth kiss is not the same as the first kiss.
So why do they insist on scientific data being
so like that when life is very different?
I think we should expect reproducibility in kind, but not precise replication.
When we push to the limit, then the whole effects get diluted.
People get bored doing experiments.
And I know that issue of replication is becoming
paramount now in the behavioral sciences.
Many, many classic studies in social psychology
and psychology and economics and related
disciplines are not replicable, even though they've been well accepted.
And that's certainly true in medicine.
Every time you turn around, there's a different
medical result than there was five years ago.
And now you've got to change your behavior
if you want protection from a certain disease
based on the latest research.
I mean, for so many years, we ate hydrogenated fats.
Then we turned back to natural fats, et cetera.
It's how it is.
Yeah, we get different advice every decade.
What's appropriate?
It used to be that fatty foods like cheese were terrible.
Now they're good.
Now, one wonders how much the belief system of the people in that time contributed to
those results.
Well, no doubt, a lot.
Yes.
And that's really where psychotronics becomes very, very interesting.
Exactly.
Well, Dr. Beverly Rubick, what a pleasure to
explore this fascinating, exotic, and potentially
very important area with you.
Thank you so much, Jeffrey.
It's my pleasure.
And thank you for being with me, and thank you for being with us.
